--- title: "The policy evaluator’s toolbox: Presenting results from randomized experiments" author: "Paw Hansen" date: '2023-05-24' categories: [statistical analysis] image: featured.jpg description: 'Sensible out-of-the-box tables and plots for your next randomized controlled trial' editor_options: chunk_output_type: console --- In this series of blog posts, I go over some of the most common experimental designs, including natural experiments such as difference-in-difference, regression discontinuity designs, and so on. The goal is to provide you with some sensible default plots and tables you can use when writing up your next experimental analysis. For more detail on the technicalities of the individual designs, check out the sources I link to at the bottom of this post. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Packages used in this post"} # Packages we'll be using today library(tidyverse) library(modelsummary) library(marginaleffects) library(kableExtra) library(ggsci) theme_set(theme_minimal(base_size = 12)) ``` ::: Today: RCTs. What better way to kick off a series on experimental designs than with a truly randomized experiment? To get started, I'll simulate some fake data we can work with. @tbl-peak shows a peak of the simulated data. ::: {#tbl-peak .cell tbl-cap='A peak at the simulated data'} ```{.r .cell-code} set.seed(2707) num_people <- 1000 treat_effect <- 4.5 dat <- tibble( age = sample(18:75, num_people, replace = T), female = sample(c(0, 1), num_people, replace = T), non_western = sample(c(0, 1), num_people, replace = T, prob = c(.85, .15)), mu = 25 + .5 * age + 8 * female -10 * non_western ) dat <- dat |> mutate(condition = sample(c("Control", "Treatment"), size = num_people, replace = TRUE), outcome = case_when( condition == "Control" ~ rnorm(num_people, mean = mu, sd = 1), condition == "Treatment" ~ rnorm(num_people, mean = mu + treat_effect, sd = 1)) ) |> select(-mu) |> mutate(female = case_when( female == 1 ~ "Female", female == 0 ~ "Male", TRUE ~ "Trouble")) |> mutate(non_western = case_when( non_western == 1 ~ "Non-western", non_western == 0 ~ "Western", TRUE ~ "Trouble")) head(dat) |> kbl() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
age female non_western condition outcome
47 Female Western Control 57.33940
47 Male Western Control 48.15630
44 Female Western Treatment 62.29194
44 Female Western Control 55.12165
63 Male Western Control 54.08326
51 Female Western Treatment 62.40755
````` ::: ::: ### Presenting descriptives First, let's make a table to see if our two groups are balanced on average. See @tbl-balance. This would be your typical "Table 1" if you were writing a research paper. ::: {#tbl-balance .cell tbl-cap='Means of covariates across experimental conditions'} ```{.r .cell-code} dat_summary <- dat |> select( Age = age, Female = female, 'Non-Western' = non_western, condition, -outcome, ) datasummary_balance(~condition, data = dat_summary) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Control (N=485)
Treatment (N=515)
Mean Std. Dev. Mean Std. Dev. Diff. in Means Std. Error
Age 46.6 16.7 47.1 16.6 0.6 1.1
N Pct. N Pct.
Female Female 237 48.9 248 48.2
Male 248 51.1 267 51.8
Non-Western Non-western 72 14.8 83 16.1
Western 413 85.2 432 83.9
````` ::: ::: Alternatively, you could reserve that table for an appendix and instead present a table showing descriptives of the full sample. @tbl-descriptives shows an examples. ::: {#tbl-descriptives .cell tbl-cap='Means of covariates for the full sample'} ```{.r .cell-code} dat_summary <- dat |> select( Age = age, Female = female, 'Non-Western' = non_western, Condition = condition, -outcome, ) datasummary_balance(~1, data = dat_summary) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Mean Std. Dev.
Age 46.9 16.6
N Pct.
Female Female 485 48.5
Male 515 51.5
Non-Western Non-western 155 15.5
Western 845 84.5
Condition Control 485 48.5
Treatment 515 51.5
````` ::: ::: ### Presenting results After presenting evidence that your randomization was successful, you should move on to present your results. This could be either as a regression table (@tbl-results) or as a figure (@fig-exp). ::: {#tbl-results .cell tbl-cap='Outcome across experimental conditions (OLS estimates)'} ```{.r .cell-code} model_basic <- lm(outcome ~ condition, data = dat) model_cov_adj <- lm(outcome ~ ., data = dat) modelsummary(models = list( "Unadjusted" = model_basic, "Covariate adjusted" = model_cov_adj), coef_rename = c( "age" = "Age (in years)", "femaleMale" = "Sex: Male", "conditionTreatment" = "Condition: Treatment", "non_westernWestern" = "Origin: Western") ) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}

````` ::: ::: I personally prefer @fig-exp because in addition to showing the model (i.e. the two group averages), it also conveys information about the full distribution of data for both groups. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} means <- dat %>% group_by(condition) %>% summarise(avg = mean(outcome), sd = sd(outcome)) avg_control <- means %>% filter(condition == "Control") %>% select(avg) dat %>% ggplot(aes(condition, outcome)) + geom_jitter(aes(color = condition), alpha = .4) + geom_hline(yintercept = avg_control$avg, linetype = "dashed", color = "grey50") + geom_pointrange(data = means, aes(x = condition, y = avg, ymin = avg + sd, ymax = avg - sd)) + labs(color = "Condition", x = NULL, y = "Outcome") + scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set1") + theme(legend.position = "none") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Outcome across experimental conditions](index_files/figure-html/fig-exp-1.png){#fig-exp width=672} ::: ::: ### Final thoughts: Presenting results from randomized experiments ### Cool! Where can I learn more? * Coppock, A. (2021). Visualize as you randomize. _Advances in experimental political science_. .
